parameters.text:
=You are a time and distance estimator agent designed to fill in either time, distacne, or both in order to complete json data for a specifc hike; we will specify which of these options later in the prompt.

Make sure the output follows the output format. If there are input fields in the input json that don't exist in the expected output json, you can drop the information; essentially means follow the output schema. You will use the other input data to make estimations, but you won't include it in the output.


Your hike specifc input data and specifc estimator task is:
{{$json["prompt"]}}


Ensure no other fields are modified. Modify the JSON according to all the rules listed in the prompt and output structure. Do not change dtypes either; reference the output to find dtypes. You can assume a number without a '.' is an int.

Just make the necesary changes to your assigned value, it is pretty simple. Focus on output structure.

=You are an information extraction agent. Your task is to read the input email and extract structured hike data in the specified JSON format.

I want you to parse hike details per gorilla family found in the body of the email. Take the details and put them in their respective output places in the json. You must follow the listed output format. 

For "difficulty" rating. Easy = 1, medium = 2, difficult = 3, extremely difficult = 4. Use your judgement to categorize the difficulty based on what the trackers say. If the trackers don't mention difficulty, record it as a 0 and I will calculate it later in the workflow. dtype of category should be int.

For "description_binary". The categories are rocky, wet, steep. Use your judgment to assign boolean values for each based of the context from the trackers for the specifc hike. If nothing mentioned assume the value is 0. Remember, the opposite of wet, are words like dry, loose gravel, etc. opposite of steep are words like flat, level, low elevation etc. Use your judgment to find opposite words to the categories and count it as 0 for that category.

For "elevation", find the number given by the tracker's context. You can put 0 if there is no context. I will go over all 0's later and fill them in so don't force it. dtype float. unit meters.

For "est_dist_km", find the hike distance given by the tracker's context, you may need to convert the units, make sure it gets recorded as kilometers. You can put 0 if there is no context. I will go over all 0's later and fill them in so don't force it. dtype float

For "est_time_min", find the hike time given by the tracker's context, you may need to convert the units, make sure it gets recorded as minutes. You can put 0 if there is no context. I will go over all 0's later and fill them in so don't don't force it. dtype int


For country string, and research boolean. completly ignore if research is true or country != "rwanda". These gorilla families must be filtered out and not including in the json output. I will have a function later in the workflow to check this, if you are unsure assume they are being reachered.



Take your time, there is also a output checker to decrease the chances of hallucinations. Ensure there are no duplicvate entries. Use "gorilla_family" as a key to ensure no duplicates. get rid of the second identical entry if they exist.

Because the information is given by gorila trackers whose first language is not english, some of the words will be misspelled. The highest risk peice of information to get right is the gorilla name. I have injected all the possible gorilla names in a global var I will link below, not all of them will be selected but all selected names must be on the list. Use it as context when assigned names.

Below is the subject followed by the body of the email:
{{ $('Raw Email Data').item.json['Email Context'] }}

Below is the list of all gorilla famillies:
{{ $json['Gorilla Family Universe'] }}

parameters.content: ## I wish I could keep my agent node while being able to see both the pre and post autofixer output. This would help we judge the effectivness of the autofixer

parameters.text:
=You are a consistency agent responsible for reviewing and improving the estimated time and distance values provided by the previous agent for a json of gorilla hike data, which will be provided below.

The agent before already made a first pass using local (individual) hike context, which is usually a good baseline.

Your job now is to:

Compare all hikes to each other, using time, distance, and the binary features steep, wet, and rocky.
Combine the given information with your own understanding of the world.


Detect inconsistencies or logical contradictions. For example but not limited to:

A hike marked as steep and rocky with greater distance should not have less time than a flat, dry, shorter hike.

Wet, steep, and long hikes should generally take longer than dry, flat, short ones.

Only modify values if they are clearly inconsistent with other hikes.

Avoid arbitrary changes.

Hikes over 12 hours or distance 20 km are most likely hallucinations and should be lowered. Keep them high if applicable but make sure they are reasonable relative to data on other hikes.

Hikes under 2 hours or distance 2 km are most likely hallucinations and should be increased. Keep them low if applicable but make sure they are reasonable relative to data on other hikes.

If the first agent's estimate seems reasonable, leave it unchanged.

This is a second-draft pass. Think in terms of internal logic and reasonableness across the set ‚Äî do not force normalization or ranking unless necessary.


Here is the allHike json data use this for context:
{{ $json.allHikes }}



Use this JSON string according and all the rules listed in the prompt and output structure to create an output json with the edited time/dist estimation. Ensure no other fields are modified besides the estimated_time_minutes and estimated_distance_km. reference the output to find dtypes. You can assume a number without a '.' is an int.

=You are a hike difficulty estimation agent responsible for filling in missing difficulty scores. For reference: 1 = easy, 2 = medium, 3 = difficult, 4 = extremely difficult, and 0 = not set yet (a score of 0 is a signal that you will need to estimate and replace that score). Additionally, you will be provided a json object containing data on each hike called Hikes. You will be expected to pull information from hikes and combine it with your understanding of the world to build your hike difficulty estimations.



Here is some inspiration for methods on predicting difficulty, you are not limited to what I suggest because I want to leverage your understanding of the world:

Compare all hikes to each other, using time, distance, and the binary features steep, wet, and rocky.
Combine the given information with your own understanding of the world.

Some difficulty scores are already in place. It is safe to assume those scores are accurate and should not be changed. Therefore it is critical to understand which parameters led to those scores. Knowing that will help aid you in the estimation of scores marked 0.

IMPORTANT INFO: The most important metric is estimated_time_minutes, estimated_distance_km, and then elevation in that order. For each of those categories, the higher the more difficult the hike ands the lower the easier thje hike. Focus on those when picking difficulty.
Make sure you consider the important info above.

Detect inconsistencies or logical contradictions. For example but not limited to:

A hike marked as steep and rocky with greater distance should be more difficulty than a flat, dry, shorter hike.

Wet and steep hikes should be more difficult than dry, flat, short ones.

Only modify values if they are makred 0.

At this stage of the workflow, non-zero difficulties are have been entered manually by trackers and assumed correct. Therefore use them as pockets of truth to build your estimations around.

Difficulty scores must be 1,2,3, or 4. If you are completly stumped mark it as a 0; this is a last resort.


Here is the Hike json data use this for context:
{{ $json.allHikes }}



Modify the JSON according to all the rules listed in the prompt and output structure. Ensure no other fields are modified besides the difficulty. Do not change dtypes either; reference the output to find dtypes. You can assume a number without a '.' is an int. Difficulty is an int.

Accuracy is more important than speed on this section.

values.content:
=Take the content inside {{ $json.body }}, which is a list of hike assignments.

Write a professional, friendly email starting with:

‚ÄúHi team,
Thank you for your patience. Here is the list of hike matchings we found:‚Äù

Then, present each assignment clearly on a separate line and add two more returns.
Use line breaks (not pipes or bullets).
Include the driver name, assigned hike, hike difficulty, group difficulty, and reason in each line.
Make sure everything is spelled correctly and consistently formatted.
End the email with a polite closing like:
‚ÄúLet us know if you have any questions.
Best regards,
The Assignment Team‚Äù

json.text:
Hello team,  Please proceed with assigning hiking groups. Below is the
latest dump from the trackers, lots of info in here, please filter
what u need. Some typos probably, sorry üòÖ

Muhuza was seen near the Gahinga loop (I think they meant Muhoza?).
Hike is steep, modr8 diffculty, mostly dry, elevation medium (est.
2100m). He‚Äôs in Rwanda, not under reserch. probably a 4 and half hour
hike.

Hirva currently by the southern moss fields. Wet, low gradient trail,
very slippery rocks, be cautious. Country: Rwanda. Being studied
currently by Dr. Kayumba. The hike should be around 7km and take 4
hours.

Kwitonda‚Äîaka ‚ÄúThe Old Man‚Äù‚Äîspotted this morning in the tree ridge
zone. Dry climb, vry steep. Rocky af. Rwanda. Not under any current
research. Hike is around 5km. Elevation close to 2400m.

Kwisnaga (pretty sure that‚Äôs Kwisanga) tracked in deep forest. Reports
unclear‚Äîpossible flooding nearby. Moderate incline, mostly muddy.
Still in Rwanda. NOT being researched. Hike will be over 6 hours,
maybe ~8km.

 Amahoro fam on patrol path near Hill 9. Mild slope, dry but scattered
rocks. Easy trail overall. They're in Uganda today, just crossed over
for the day. Active study group. Elevation ~2000m, est. time 2 hrs.

Sabyinyo heard grunting near trailhead exit 2. Low elevation
(1900ish), mostly flat trail, some bamboo brush. Rwanda. Not under
research. Est. 1.5 hr trek, maybe 3.5km.

  Igisha showing high activity on western ridgeline. Very muddy and
steep. Elevation ~2800m. Being monitored for aggression patterns by
team. Hike is 10-11km, plan for 4+ hrs. Rwanda. Researched.

Umubano chillin by the shallow creek beds. Wet path but steady slope.
Rwanda, elevation ~2150m. Non-research group. Expect 5.5km walk, ~2.5
hrs.

Agashya got seen higher up the saddle ridge. Final approach is
tough‚Äîscree slope + dense forest. Rwanda. Not in a study. Elevation
~2500m. Expect 3.5-4 hrs, ~9km.

Susa is doing Susa things‚Äîtop of the world again. Elevation 3000m+,
foggy as hell. Very steep trail. Not researched. You‚Äôre lookin at 5 hr
hike min.

 Kigoma foraging near west trails. Rocky trail but not awful. Rwanda.
No research. ~2.5 hrs, est. 5km. Elevation ~2200m.

Kureba seen playing around bamboo zone B. Pretty wet rn, steep at
times. Rwanda group. Hike is 7.5km, takes 3 hrs on avg. Elevation
~2550m.

Titus near the big fig tree ridge. Partially sunny, dry trail,
moderate incline. Rwanda. Elevation est. 2450m. 6km distance, not
studied.

Pablo found near stream split between zones 3 & 4. Rocky crossing but
no major slope. Rwanda. ~5km in. Non-research. Elevation 2150m.

Dushishoze def. still on Ugandan side today. Long hike, very foggy.
Trail is slick and uphil almost whole way. ~2800m elevation. 4 hrs.
Not in a study.

Musirikare (U) is in the upper highlands sector. Mostly dry but
exposed. Under research by Dr. Nyirakaragire. Trail is 6km with minor
scrambles. Elevation ~2300m.

Urwego chillin near old bamboo grove checkpoint. Easy-ish trail, flat
most of the way. Rwanda, 2000m elevation. No research. ~2 hrs, maybe
4km.

Ntambara was climbing earlier‚Äîsteep trail. Rocky and dry, 8km hike or
so. Rwanda, elevation 2550m. Non-research.

 Isimbi located on northeast slope this morning. Moderate trail, very
wet after rain. Not under study. Elevation ~2400m. ~3 hrs on foot.

Segasira was seen literally next to the vehicle access point. Trail
flat and dry. Elevation ~1800m. Good for newbies. Rwanda.

Mutobo found above the northwest cliffs. Rocky switchbacks. Rwanda,
2150m elevation. Not studied. ~2.5 hrs in and out.

Muhabura = HARD. Like always. Volcano side. Very steep. 14km hike.
Rwanda. Elevation ~3100m. No current study.  Izuba basking (lol) in
meadow sector B. Flat trail, dry. 1.5 hr hike tops. Elevation ~1850m.
Rwanda. No research.
json.textAsHtml:
Hello team, Please proceed with assigning hiking groups. Below is the
latest dump from the trackers, lots of info in here, please filter
what u need. Some typos probably, sorry 😅

Muhuza was seen near the Gahinga loop (I think they meant Muhoza?).
Hike is steep, modr8 diffculty, mostly dry, elevation medium (est.
2100m). He’s in Rwanda, not under reserch. probably a 4 and half hour
hike.

Hirva currently by the southern moss fields. Wet, low gradient trail,
very slippery rocks, be cautious. Country: Rwanda. Being studied
currently by Dr. Kayumba. The hike should be around 7km and take 4
hours.

Kwitonda—aka “The Old Man”—spotted this morning in the tree ridge
zone. Dry climb, vry steep. Rocky af. Rwanda. Not under any current
research. Hike is around 5km. Elevation close to 2400m.

Kwisnaga (pretty sure that’s Kwisanga) tracked in deep forest. Reports
unclear—possible flooding nearby. Moderate incline, mostly muddy.
Still in Rwanda. NOT being researched. Hike will be over 6 hours,
maybe ~8km.

Amahoro fam on patrol path near Hill 9. Mild slope, dry but scattered
rocks. Easy trail overall. They're in Uganda today, just crossed over
for the day. Active study group. Elevation ~2000m, est. time 2 hrs.

(1900ish), mostly flat trail, some bamboo brush. Rwanda. Not under
research. Est. 1.5 hr trek, maybe 3.5km.

team. Hike is 10-11km, plan for 4+ hrs. Rwanda. Researched.

No research. ~2.5 hrs, est. 5km. Elevation ~2200m.

Ntambara was climbing earlier—steep trail. Rocky and dry, 8km hike or

Segasira was seen literally next to the vehicle access point. Trail
flat and dry. Elevation ~1800m. Good for newbies. Rwanda.

Mutobo found above the northwest cliffs. Rocky switchbacks. Rwanda,
2150m elevation. Not studied. ~2.5 hrs in and out.

Muhabura = HARD. Like always. Volcano side. Very steep. 14km hike.
Rwanda. Elevation ~3100m. No current study. Izuba basking (lol) in
meadow sector B. Flat trail, dry. 1.5 hr hike tops. Elevation ~1850m.
Rwanda. No research.
